name: Tavë Kosi
description: A traditional Albanian dish of baked lamb and rice, topped with a yogurt and egg mixture.
steps: Brown lamb pieces in a skillet with a little oil.
Place lamb in a baking dish and cover with rice and water.
Bake in the oven at 375°F for 30 minutes.
Whisk together yogurt, eggs, and flour; pour over the lamb and rice.
Return to oven and bake until the topping is golden and set.
Serve hot.
tips: Ensure the lamb is tender before adding the yogurt mixture.
Serve with a side of fresh salad to balance the richness of the dish.
Can substitute lamb with chicken for a different flavor.

name: Bakllasarem
description: A sweet pastry filled with a mixture of walnuts, sugar, and cinnamon, similar to baklava.
steps: Prepare phyllo dough and layer half in a greased baking dish.
Mix chopped walnuts, sugar, and cinnamon; spread over the phyllo.
Top with the remaining phyllo, brushing each layer with melted butter.
Cut into diamonds and bake at 350°F until golden and crisp.
Pour syrup made from sugar, water, and lemon juice over the hot pastry.
Allow to cool before serving.
tips: Cut the pastry before baking to make serving easier.
Ensure the syrup is hot when poured over the cooled pastry to absorb properly.
Can add clove or cardamom to the syrup for extra flavor.

name: Fërgesë
description: A hearty dish of peppers, tomatoes, and cottage cheese, often served as a warm side dish or main course.
steps: Sauté chopped onions and bell peppers in olive oil until soft.
Add chopped tomatoes and simmer until the mixture thickens.
Stir in crumbled cottage cheese and season with salt and pepper.
Cook until everything is heated through.
Serve warm with crusty bread.
tips: Add chili flakes for a spicy kick.
Can be made ahead and reheated, enhancing the flavors.
Perfect as a vegetarian main course.

name: Speca të mbushur
description: Bell peppers stuffed with rice, herbs, and seafood, baked until tender.
steps: Prepare rice according to package instructions.
Mix cooked rice with chopped herbs, garlic, and precooked shrimp.
Cut tops off bell peppers and remove seeds.
Stuff peppers with rice mixture, place in a baking dish.
Bake at 375°F until peppers are soft and filling is hot.
Serve with lemon wedges.
tips: Ensure the rice is not overcooked as it will bake further in the oven.
Can use a mix of seafood like shrimp and scallops.
Top with cheese for the last 10 minutes of baking for a melty crust.

name: Byrek me Spinaq
description: A savory pie made with phyllo dough, filled with spinach and feta cheese.
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Sauté spinach until wilted, then mix with crumbled feta cheese and eggs.
Layer phyllo sheets in a greased baking pan, brushing each with oil.
Spread spinach mixture over phyllo, then cover with more phyllo sheets.
Bake until golden brown.
Cut into squares and serve.
tips: Keep the phyllo dough covered with a damp towel while working to prevent it from drying out.
Add onions to the spinach mixture for extra flavor.
Serve with yogurt for breakfast or a light lunch.

name: Jani me fasule
description: A traditional bean stew slowly cooked with onions, tomatoes, and spices.
steps: Soak beans overnight, then drain and rinse.
Sauté onions and garlic in a pot until translucent.
Add beans, water, and chopped tomatoes. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer.
Cook covered on low heat for 2 hours until beans are tender.
Season with salt, pepper, and a pinch of chili powder.
Serve hot with bread.
tips: Check water level during cooking and add more if needed to prevent sticking.
Can be served with pickled vegetables for added flavor.
Leftovers taste even better the next day as flavors meld.

name: Shëndetli
description: A walnut cake soaked in syrup, often served during special occasions and holidays.
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Prepare cake batter with eggs, sugar, and ground walnuts.
Pour into a greased pan and bake until a toothpick comes out clean.
Simultaneously, prepare syrup with sugar, water, and lemon juice.
Pour hot syrup over the hot cake after removing from oven.
Let absorb and cool before serving.
tips: Do not underbake the cake; ensure it is fully set to absorb the syrup.
Pierce the cake with a fork before pouring syrup to enhance absorption.
Serve with a dollop of whipped cream or vanilla ice cream.

name: Qifqi
description: Rice balls seasoned with mint and fried until crispy, a popular dish from Gjirokastër.
steps: Cook rice until tender, then mix with beaten eggs, chopped mint, and salt.
Heat oil in a deep skillet.
Form rice mixture into small balls and fry until golden and crispy.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot.
tips: Use short-grain rice for better stickiness and forming.
Add finely chopped onions to the rice mixture for extra flavor.
Serve with plain yogurt or tzatziki for dipping.

name: Përime në zgare
description: A variety of grilled vegetables, typically seasoned with olive oil, salt, and herbs.
steps: Slice zucchini, bell peppers, eggplants, and tomatoes into even pieces.
Marinate with olive oil, garlic, and herbs.
Grill on high heat until vegetables are tender and have grill marks.
Serve hot or at room temperature, garnished with fresh basil.
tips: Ensure the grill is very hot before adding vegetables to get good sear marks.
Can be served as a side dish or as a vegetarian main course.
Drizzle with balsamic vinegar before serving for added flavor.

name: Mish me midhje
description: A seafood dish featuring sautéed mussels with garlic, wine, and fresh herbs, often served over pasta or with crusty bread.
steps: Clean mussels and discard any that are open and do not close when tapped.
Heat olive oil in a large skillet, add minced garlic, and sauté until fragrant.
Add mussels and cover with white wine, simmer until mussels open.
Sprinkle with chopped parsley and serve hot.
Serve with pasta or fresh bread.
tips: Always use fresh mussels for the best flavor.
Discard any mussels that do not open after cooking.
Add a pinch of chili flakes for a spicy version.
